Award.AwardTitle: BREAD: Engineering Broad-spectrum Resistance Against Multiple Geminiviruses and Cassava Brown Streak Viruses Using Synthetic Trans-acting Small Interfering RNA (tasiRNA)
Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Vincent Fondong (Delaware State University)
Co-PIs: Oumar Doungous (Delaware State University), Kone Mongomake (Delaware State University), Stephan Winter (German Collection of Microorganisms and Cell Cultures Braunschweig, Germany)

Cassava is an important staple food crop to more than 500 million people worldwide, most of whom live in sub-Saharan Africa. In tropical and subtropical regions of Africa, the cassava crop is infected by viruses belonging to Geminiviridae and Potyviridae families, which are the two most important plant viruses in the world. Members of the Geminiviridae family cause the cassava mosaic disease while the Potyviridae cause the cassava brown streak disease. So far, seven virus species of the Geminiviridae family and two species of the Potyviridae have been identified across Africa. These viruses are increasingly occurring in mixed infections, causing synergistic interactions that result in severe symptoms and almost total crop loss. Currently, control of these viruses is through the use of resistant plant varieties coupled with various management strategies. However, transfer of resistance using conventional breeding is limited by several factors including lack of useful genes in core cassava germplasm collections, heterozygosity and allopolyploidy, irregular flowering, and low fertility rates. Thus, although classical breeding efforts have proved to be instrumental in developing virus resistant cassava varieties, it is complicated and slow, and is unlikely to provide a lasting solution to the fast spreading virus disease pandemics. This emphasizes the need for the development of new approaches to contain these viruses. The goal of this project is to design synthetic trans-acting small interfering RNAs (tasiRNAs) from conserved regions of cassava viruses with the capability of targeting members of virus families causing cassava diseases across Africa. TasiRNAs have been shown to be efficient in targeting RNA transcripts, including virus transcripts, and is thus a potentially powerful tool for the control of plant viruses. Because synthetic tasiRNAs of greater than 21 nucleotides are sufficient to efficiently silence cognate genes, this technology provides an unprecedented opportunity to target many viruses using small transgene constructs. This approach is more efficient than the current strategy based on long hairpin transgene constructs, which are unstable and are characterized by inefficient spread of the siRNA to appropriate targets.

This project will contribute significantly to cassava virus control efforts in Africa. The project will also provide unique training opportunities in molecular biology to two African co-PIs who will use the technologies in their home institutions. Two postdoctoral researchers and six undergraduate students will be trained in the project. Anticipated outcomes include transgene constructs and DNA sequences with the potential to control cassava viruses. Results and materials generated from this research will be accessible to the scientific community through the Delaware State University website (http://www.appliedplantbiotech.com/index.html) and at the Co-PI website in Germany (http://www.dsmz.de/).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Optimization of cassava regeneration and transformation procedures: An important prerequisite to developing a genetic transformation system for plants is the availability of morphogenic culture that can easily be used in gene transfer techniques. In cassava, the most efficient procedure to producing morphogenic culture is through somatic embryogenesis, which has become an integral component of genetic transformation systems in cassava. Because different cassava cultivars respond differently to regeneration, we optimized and published procedures for 14 different African cassava cultivars.

Assessment of tasiRNA constructs for resistance to cassava viruses: Trans-acting siRNA (TAS) genes have been identified in all examined land plants, including cassava. TAS genes differ from most genes in that they do not code for a protein, but rather they produce a long non-coding transcript that is subsequently processed into multiple trans-acting small interfering RNAs (tasiRNAs). Each tasiRNA is 21 nucleotides long and typically one or two conserved tasiRNAs from a TAS transcript targets a protein-coding messenger RNA (mRNA) in the cell by binding to the target mRNA and directing cleaving and degradation of that mRNA. Consequently, there is a reduction in transcript levels leading to reduction in the protein level and disruption of its function. Since the cassava plant uses TAS genes to regulate other genes, we can modify its TAS genes (using synthetic tasiRNAs, or “syn-tasiRNAs”) to target mRNAs of interest, such as viral mRNAs thereby control the virus.

            We used this approach to construct transgenes that target cassava mosaic geminiviruses and cassava brown streak potyviruses that infect cassava across the African continent. Because sequences as small as 21 nucleotides can silence targeted genes, we designed sequences from multiple cassava viruses belonging to different virus families in individual constructs so as to use on construct in targeting multiple viruses. These constructs were first tested in Nicotiana benthamiana model plant to confirm efficacy in conferring a virus resistance prior to transfer to the more difficult-to-transform cassava. In the labs of Stephan Winter in Germany (co-PI of this project) and my lab, we have generated eight different constructs and transformed cassava with. Some of the constructs confer resistance to several of the cassava viruses tested. Many transgenic cassava lines are now being molecularly characterized.

Development of a cassava small RNA database:  The TAS genes used to produce resistance transgenes when this study started were from Arabidopsis given that such genes had not been determined in cassava. For future studies, therefore, we sought to identify endogenous cassava TAS genes and their microRNA triggers. Small RNA libraries from cassava stem, leaf, callus, male and female flower tissues were prepared, deep sequenced and analyzed. Because such data is critically important in cassava research, we established a publicly available cassava small RNA database (https://mpss.danforthcenter.org/dbs/index.php?SITE=cassava_sRNA).

 Broader Impact: One of the kay aims of this project was research training. For the four years of the project, we trained over 20 undergraduate and graduate students in molecular biology and tissue culture techniques. Five postdoctoral researchers, one of whom came on a Fulbright Foundation fellowship, were also trained.
